Award.AwardTitle: Research Coordination Network for Haemosporida of Terrestrial Vertebrates: A Model Parasite-Host System
Award.AbstractNarration:
Haemosporida, malaria blood parasites, are diverse and widespread and are major parasites and pathogens of birds, reptiles, and mammals, including humans and domestic animals. Despite their ecological, evolutionary, and public health importance, these parasites, their distribution, and their evolutionary biology are poorly known, in large part owing to the dearth of trained investigators familiar with the molecular techniques required to identify infections in wild populations. Additionally, Haemosporida form a model group for study of host-specificity of disease organisms and the emergence of novel diseases through such mechanisms as host-switching.

This Research Coordination Network (RCN) will improve understanding of malaria blood parasites, and of the disease risks they entail, through an integrated set of actions. The RCN will establish and operate a website to provide information, sources of data, and tools for parasite identification, and will contribute to advancing ability to classify these single-celled blood parasites that are known primarily from DNA sequences obtained from the blood of infected hosts. A major feature of the RCN will be the establishment of one-week summer schools with intensive training for young investigators, particularly from developing countries, in the techniques of working with malaria parasites, from collecting blood samples in the field to the molecular lab techniques for obtaining DNA sequence data and using the analytical tools to interpret their findings. The Network will be completely open to interested individuals and will serve as a forum for promoting research and collaboration on these model disease organisms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The “Malaria RCN” was designed to (a) provide training for young investigators in techniques for research on haemosporidian parasites of vertebrates (primarily parasites in the genera Plasmodium, Haemoproteus, and Leucocytozoon), which are the causative agents of malaria and other blood-borne diseases; (b) provide financial support for researchers to attend international meetings; and (c) provide financial support for students to visit established laboratories to learn new techniques and carry out small research projects. During the past grant year (April 1, 2015—March 31, 2016), which has been the fifth year of the Malaria RCN project, our principal activities were to hold the Fourth International Workshop on Malaria and Related Haemosporidian Parasites of Wildlife, September 28-October 1, 2015, at the National Conservation Training Center (NCTC) in Shepherdstown, West Virginia. The workshop was led by seven internationally known researchers on haemosporidian parasites, who are also members of the RCN steering committee and co-PIs on the supporting NSF grant: Carter Atkinson, USGS Pacific Island Ecosystems Research Center; Staffan Bensch, Lund University, Sweden; Robert Fleischer, Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute; Susan Perkins, American Museum of Natural History; Robert Ricklefs, University of Missouri, St. Louis; Ravinder Sehgal, San Francisco State University; Gediminas Valkiunas, Nature Research Centre, Vilnius, Lithuania. The teaching assistant for the workshop was Leticia Soares, a Brazilian doctoral student at the University of Missouri-St. Louis. The workshop covered field and laboratory techniques for capturing birds, obtaining blood samples, making blood smears, mosquito salivary gland preparations, vector identification, parasite identification and taxonomy, and a discussion of parasite evolution and systematics. All students and faculty presented brief talks on their work. Web resources (Genbank, Malavi database) were discussed and students carried out DNA sequence alignments and phylogenetic reconstruction techniques. The workshop was attended by 27 students from 11 countries (United States 12, United Kingdom 2, India 1, Spain 3, Sweden 2, Colombia 1, Russia 1, Mexico 1, Peru 2, Brazil 1, Germany 1).

The 2015 workshop was similar to three workshops held at the NCTC in previous years, bringing the total number of students who have received this training to about 100. We have also held smaller workshops covering much of the same material in Peru (twice) and Cameroon.

In addition, continuing a program from previous years, small grants were made to 6 students to visit laboratories to learn techniques and carry out research projects: Arif Ciloglu (Turkey) to visit the Valkiunas laboratory in Vilnius, Lithuania, to learn parasite identification; Karina Ivanova (Bulgaria), to present research results at the 2015 EOU Conference in Badajos, Spain; Paolo Pulgarin (Colombia), to present research results at the International Ornithological Congress in Manaus, Brazil; Hafaliana Christian Ranaivoson (Madagascar), to work on malaria parasites of fruit bats in the laboratory of Dr. Susan Perkins at the American Museum of Natural History in New York; Josh Robertson (United Kingdom), to visit the laboratory of R. E. Ricklefs in St. Louis Missouri to screen blood samples of West Indian seabirds for blood parasites; Alparslan Yildirim (Turkey) to visit the Valkiunas laboratory in Vilnius, Lithuania, to learn identification of haemosporidian parasites.

The MalariaRCN has also subsidized travel by several scientists to attend the Third International Conference on Malaria and Related Haemosporidian Parasites of Wildlife at Cappadocia, Turkey, September 25-29, 2016.
